thread.title: Norwegian Air to operate new flights from Belfast to US
thread.title_full: Norwegian Air to operate new flights from Belfast to US

title: Norwegian Air to operate new flights from Belfast to US
text:
Norwegian Air to operate new flights from Belfast to US By Julian O'Neill BBC News NI Business Correspondent 23 February 2017 Close share panel Image caption It is believed flights from Belfast International to the US will begin this summer Low-cost carrier Norwegian Air is set to begin flights between Northern Ireland and the United States. 
Details will be announced later, but it has been looking at services to airports near New York and Boston. 
Belfast International Airport has been in talks with the airline for months and it is believed operations will begin from the summer. 
The airport has been working to find a replacement to United Airlines, who ended its New York service in January. 
United had claimed the Belfast-Newark route was not profitable enough. 
Weeks ago, Economy Minister Simon Hamilton told the assembly he had approved unspecified financial assistance for two new routes. Image copyright Norwegian Image caption The carrier is also scheduled to announce new transatlantic services from Dublin and Cork 
This was a reference to Norwegian Air's operations. 
It uses Stewart International Airport, about 70 miles from New York, and TF Green Airport, 60 miles from Boston. 
The carrier is also scheduled to announce new transatlantic services from Dublin and Cork later. 
Its chief executive, Bjorn Kjos, has been quoted as saying transatlantic flights from Ireland should on average cost about $300 (Â£241) to $350 return.
